questions.text: What does HTML stand for?
questions.explanation: HTML stands for Hyper Text Markup Language, the standard language for creating web pages.

questions.text: Who is considered the father of the World Wide Web?
questions.explanation: Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1989 while working at CERN.

questions.text: Which programming language was created by Guido van Rossum in 1991?
questions.explanation: Python was created by Guido van Rossum and first released in 1991.

questions.text: What year was the first iPhone released?
questions.explanation: The first iPhone was released by Apple on June 29, 2007.

questions.text: What does CPU stand for?
questions.explanation: CPU stands for Central Processing Unit, the primary component that executes instructions in a computer.

questions.text: Which company developed the Java programming language?
questions.explanation: Java was developed by James Gosling at Sun Microsystems and released in 1995.

questions.text: What was the first commercially successful web browser?
questions.explanation: Netscape Navigator, released in 1994, was the first commercially successful web browser.

questions.text: What does RAM stand for?
questions.explanation: RAM stands for Random Access Memory, a type of volatile computer memory.

questions.text: Who co-founded Apple Computer with Steve Jobs?
questions.explanation: Steve Wozniak co-founded Apple Computer with Steve Jobs and Ronald Wayne in 1976.

questions.text: What does the acronym SQL stand for?
questions.explanation: SQL stands for Structured Query Language, used for managing relational databases.

questions.text: In what year was Facebook (now Meta) founded?
questions.explanation: Facebook was founded by Mark Zuckerberg and others on February 4, 2004.

questions.text: What is the name of the Linux kernel creator?
questions.explanation: Linus Torvalds created the Linux kernel in 1991 while a student at the University of Helsinki.

questions.text: Which company manufactures the GPU line called GeForce?
questions.explanation: NVIDIA manufactures the GeForce line of graphics processing units.

questions.text: What does HTTP stand for?
questions.explanation: HTTP stands for Hyper Text Transfer Protocol, the foundation of data communication on the web.

questions.text: Who is known as the father of computer science?
questions.explanation: Alan Turing is widely considered the father of computer science and artificial intelligence.

questions.text: What was the first search engine on the internet?
questions.explanation: Archie, created in 1990 by Alan Emtage, is considered the first internet search engine.

questions.text: Which programming language is primarily used for iOS app development?
questions.explanation: Swift is Apple's programming language introduced in 2014 for iOS and macOS development.

questions.text: What does VPN stand for?
questions.explanation: VPN stands for Virtual Private Network, which encrypts internet connections for privacy.

questions.text: What year was Google founded?
questions.explanation: Google was founded by Larry Page and Sergey Brin on September 4, 1998.

questions.text: Which of these is NOT an operating system?
questions.explanation: Oracle is a database and cloud computing company, not an operating system.

questions.text: What does the 'C' in CSS stand for?
questions.explanation: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets, used to style HTML documents.

questions.text: Who developed the C programming language?
questions.explanation: Dennis Ritchie developed the C programming language at Bell Labs between 1969 and 1973.

questions.text: What is the maximum number of characters in a standard tweet (as of X/Twitter's original format)?
questions.explanation: Twitter originally had a 140-character limit per tweet, later expanded to 280 in 2017.

questions.text: What technology does Bluetooth use to transmit data?
questions.explanation: Bluetooth uses short-range radio waves in the 2.4 GHz ISM band to transmit data.

questions.text: What does GPU stand for?
questions.explanation: GPU stands for Graphics Processing Unit, a specialized processor for rendering graphics.

questions.text: Which company created the Android operating system?
questions.explanation: Android was originally created by Android Inc., founded by Andy Rubin. Google later acquired the company in 2005.

questions.text: What is the name of the protocol used to send email?
questions.explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is the standard protocol for sending email.

questions.text: In binary, what is the decimal number 10?
questions.explanation: The decimal number 10 is 1010 in binary (8+0+2+0).

questions.text: What does IoT stand for?
questions.explanation: IoT stands for Internet of Things, referring to physical devices connected to the internet.

questions.text: Which programming language was the first to be used on the web for client-side scripting?
questions.explanation: JavaScript, created by Brendan Eich at Netscape in 1995, was the first client-side scripting language for the web.

questions.text: What was IBM's first personal computer called?
questions.explanation: The IBM PC (Model 5150), released in 1981, was IBM's first personal computer.

questions.text: What type of attack floods a server with traffic to make it unavailable?
questions.explanation: A DDoS (Distributed Denial of Service) attack floods a server with traffic to overwhelm it.

questions.text: What does SSD stand for in computing?
questions.explanation: SSD stands for Solid State Drive, a storage device that uses flash memory instead of spinning disks.

questions.text: Who founded Amazon?
questions.explanation: Jeff Bezos founded Amazon in 1994, initially as an online bookstore.

questions.text: What programming paradigm treats computation as the evaluation of mathematical functions?
questions.explanation: Functional programming treats computation as evaluation of mathematical functions and avoids mutable state.

questions.text: What does the term 'open source' mean?

options.A: Software that is free of charge
options.B: Software whose source code is publicly available

questions.explanation: Open source refers to software whose source code is publicly available for anyone to view, modify, and distribute.

questions.text: Which company acquired GitHub in 2018?
questions.explanation: Microsoft acquired GitHub in 2018 for approximately $7.5 billion.

questions.text: What is phishing?

options.A: A method to speed up internet connections
options.B: A fraudulent attempt to obtain sensitive information by disguising as a trustworthy entity
options.C: A programming technique for data retrieval

questions.explanation: Phishing is a cyberattack where attackers impersonate legitimate entities to steal sensitive data.

questions.text: What was the name of the first programmable general-purpose electronic computer?
questions.explanation: ENIAC (Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer), completed in 1945, was the first programmable general-purpose electronic computer.

questions.text: What does API stand for?
questions.explanation: API stands for Application Programming Interface, a set of rules for software components to communicate.

questions.text: Which language is known as the backbone of the Unix operating system?
questions.explanation: The C programming language was developed alongside Unix, and Unix was largely rewritten in C in 1973.

questions.text: What is the smallest unit of data in a computer?
questions.explanation: A bit (binary digit) is the smallest unit of data, representing a single 0 or 1.

questions.text: Which social media platform was launched first?
questions.explanation: LinkedIn launched in May 2003, before Facebook (2004), Twitter (2006), and Instagram (2010).

questions.text: What does DNS stand for?
questions.explanation: DNS stands for Domain Name System, which translates domain names into IP addresses.

questions.text: Who is credited with writing the first computer program?
questions.explanation: Ada Lovelace is credited with writing the first algorithm intended for a machine, for Babbage's Analytical Engine in 1843.

questions.text: What type of malware encrypts files and demands payment for their release?
questions.explanation: Ransomware encrypts a victim's files and demands payment (ransom) for the decryption key.

questions.text: What does the acronym LAN stand for?
questions.explanation: LAN stands for Local Area Network, a network covering a small geographic area like a building.

questions.text: Which programming language is commonly used for data science and machine learning?
questions.explanation: Python is the most popular language for data science and machine learning, with libraries like NumPy, Pandas, and TensorFlow.

questions.text: What year was Wikipedia launched?
questions.explanation: Wikipedia was launched on January 15, 2001 by Jimmy Wales and Larry Sanger.

questions.text: What is the name of Google's AI system that defeated a world champion Go player?
questions.explanation: AlphaGo, developed by DeepMind (a Google subsidiary), defeated Go champion Lee Sedol in 2016.

questions.text: How many bytes are in a kilobyte (in the binary convention)?
questions.explanation: In the binary convention (kibibyte), a kilobyte is 1024 bytes (2 to the power of 10).

questions.text: Which company developed the first commercially available hard disk drive?
questions.explanation: IBM introduced the first commercial hard disk drive, the IBM 350 RAMAC, in 1956.

questions.text: What does CSS Grid Layout provide that Flexbox does not?
questions.explanation: CSS Grid provides two-dimensional layout (rows and columns simultaneously), while Flexbox is one-dimensional.

questions.text: What was the first video ever uploaded to YouTube?
questions.explanation: The first YouTube video, 'Me at the zoo,' was uploaded by co-founder Jawed Karim on April 23, 2005.

questions.text: What programming concept allows a function to call itself?
questions.explanation: Recursion is when a function calls itself to solve a problem by breaking it into smaller subproblems.

questions.text: Which tech company's motto was formerly 'Don't be evil'?
questions.explanation: Google's original corporate code of conduct included the motto 'Don't be evil.'

questions.text: What is the most widely used version control system?
questions.explanation: Git, created by Linus Torvalds in 2005, is the most widely used version control system in software development.

questions.text: What does BIOS stand for?
questions.explanation: BIOS stands for Basic Input Output System, firmware used to initialize hardware during booting.

questions.text: Which encryption standard is considered most secure for Wi-Fi networks?
questions.explanation: WPA3 is the latest and most secure Wi-Fi encryption standard, introduced in 2018.

questions.text: What does the term 'bug' in software originate from?

options.A: A coding error found by Alan Turing
options.B: A moth found in a Harvard Mark II computer
options.C: An error in the first ENIAC program
options.D: A term coined by Bill Gates

questions.explanation: In 1947, Grace Hopper's team found an actual moth in the Harvard Mark II relay, popularizing the term 'bug.'

questions.text: Which company created the Rust programming language?
questions.explanation: Rust was originally developed by Graydon Hoare at Mozilla Research, first appearing in 2010.

questions.text: What is Moore's Law?

options.B: The number of transistors on a chip doubles roughly every two years
options.C: Computer prices halve every five years
options.D: Battery life doubles every three years

questions.explanation: Moore's Law, observed by Intel co-founder Gordon Moore, predicts transistor density on chips doubles approximately every two years.

questions.text: What was the first popular peer-to-peer file sharing service?
questions.explanation: Napster, launched in 1999, was the first widely popular peer-to-peer file sharing service.

questions.text: What is a 'container' in software development?

options.B: A lightweight, portable unit that packages code and dependencies together

questions.explanation: A container is a lightweight package of code and its dependencies that can run consistently across environments. Docker popularized this concept.

questions.text: What does USB stand for?
questions.explanation: USB stands for Universal Serial Bus, a standard connector for data transfer and power delivery.

questions.text: Which AI research lab created ChatGPT?
questions.explanation: ChatGPT was created by OpenAI and launched in November 2022.

questions.text: What is the primary function of a firewall?

options.B: Monitor and filter network traffic based on security rules
options.C: Encrypt files on a hard drive

questions.explanation: A firewall monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules.

questions.text: Which company originally developed the TypeScript programming language?
questions.explanation: TypeScript was developed by Microsoft, led by Anders Hejlsberg, and first released in 2012.

questions.text: What is the primary difference between HTTP and HTTPS?
questions.explanation: HTTPS adds a layer of encryption using TLS/SSL to secure data transmitted between browser and server.

questions.text: What was the original name of Windows when it was first announced?
questions.explanation: Windows was originally named 'Interface Manager' before being renamed to Windows before its 1985 release.

questions.text: What data structure uses FIFO (First In, First Out) ordering?
questions.explanation: A queue follows FIFO ordering, where the first element added is the first one removed.

questions.text: Which company developed the Kotlin programming language?
questions.explanation: Kotlin was developed by JetBrains and first released in 2011. Google later adopted it as a preferred language for Android.

questions.text: What was the first social media platform to reach one billion users?
questions.explanation: Facebook reached one billion monthly active users in October 2012, the first social media platform to do so.

questions.text: What does NFC stand for in mobile technology?
questions.explanation: NFC stands for Near Field Communication, a short-range wireless technology used for contactless payments and data sharing.

questions.text: Which IBM computer defeated chess world champion Garry Kasparov in 1997?
questions.explanation: IBM's Deep Blue defeated Garry Kasparov in a six-game match in May 1997.

questions.text: What is a 'stack overflow' in programming?

options.A: A popular Q&A website for developers
options.B: When a program's call stack exceeds its allocated memory

questions.explanation: A stack overflow occurs when a program's call stack exceeds its memory limit, often caused by infinite recursion.

questions.text: What does the 'P' in TCP/IP stand for?
questions.explanation: TCP/IP stands for Transmission Control Protocol / Internet Protocol.

questions.text: Which company manufactured the first commercially available transistor radio?
questions.explanation: The Regency TR-1, made by Regency Electronics using Texas Instruments transistors, was the first commercial transistor radio in 1954.

questions.text: What is two-factor authentication (2FA)?

options.B: A security method requiring two distinct forms of identification
options.C: Logging in from two devices simultaneously

questions.explanation: Two-factor authentication requires two different types of verification (e.g., password plus a code sent to your phone).

questions.text: What programming language was originally called 'Oak'?
questions.explanation: Java was originally named Oak by James Gosling, after an oak tree outside his office. It was renamed to Java in 1995.
